docs.lead_paragraph: A majority of Americans say that the nation's economy is in its worst shape in nearly a decade and that President Bush and Congressional leaders are spending too much time talking about Iraq while neglecting problems at home, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll found signs of economic distress that cut across party and geographic lines. Nearly half of all Americans are worried that they or someone in their household will be out of a job within a year.

headline.main: PUBLIC SAYS BUSH NEEDS TO PAY HEED TO WEAK ECONOMY

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News Poll finds majority of Americans feel nation's economy is in its worst shape in nearly decade and that Pres Bush and Congressional leaders are spending too much time dealing with Iraq while neglecting problems at home; signs of economic distress cut across party and geographic lines, and nearly half of all Americans are worried that they or member of household will lose job within year; number who said they believe economy is worse than two years ago has increased markedly since summer; 41 percent who approve of way Pres Bush is handling economy is lowest in his presidency; many Americans worry that war with Iraq will disrupt already unsettled economy; despite emphasis by Pres Bush since Labor Day on need to move against Saddam Hussein, support for such policy has not changed appreciably since then; other findings of poll detailed; charts; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: A majority of Americans say that the nation's economy is in its worst shape in nearly a decade and that President Bush and Congressional leaders are spending too much time talking about Iraq while neglecting problems at home, according to the latest...

byline.original: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and JANET ELDER

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court that opens its new term on Monday is in many respects a court in waiting. The court has already accepted 45 cases for decision -- more than half the number of cases it will decide during the entire nine-month term, and enough to fill the justices' argument calendar into February. These cases are likely to produce important decisions on criminal law, immigration, federalism, copyright law, hate speech and health care, among other topics.

headline.main: Crucial Issues Wait in Wings For the Justices

docs.abstract: US Supreme Court opens new term on October 7 facing raft of crucial issues; has already accepted 45 cases for decision, more than half number of cases it will decide during entire nine-month tenure; will examine California's three-strikes law to decide whether mandatory 25-years-to-life sentences amount to cruel and inhuman punishment; will rule on hate speech, examining Virginia law that makes it crime to burn cross with intent of intimidating person or groups of persons; will examine challenge to 1998 copyright law; will examine case challenging Congress's authority requiring states to give employees unpaid leave to deal with family medical emergencies; will rule on constitutionality of mandatory detention provision of 1996 immigration law; will review state's effort to regulate aspects of managed care; may hear challenge to University of Michigan's consideration of race in admission to its law school and undergraduate program; cases growing out of war on terrorism that are currently wending way through lower courts could also give justices chance to decide important questions on limits of government power; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court that opens its new term on Monday is in many respects a court in waiting.    The court has already accepted 45 cases for decision -- more than half the number of cases it will decide during the entire nine-month term, and enough to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many customers of health maintenance organizations say they believe that half of their premiums go toward H.M.O. expenses and profit rather than medical care, according to a poll sponsored by a health insurance provider. The poll, conducted by Zogby International from Sept. 16 to Sept. 21, surveyed 802 BlueCross BlueShield customers in upstate New York. The average respondent said 26.8 percent of premiums was spent on business expenses, 23.7 percent became profit, and only 49.5 percent of premiums was spent on medical care. Excellus Inc., which runs BlueCross upstate and sponsored the poll, said it spent 90 percent of premiums on medical care. Hope Reeves (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: H.M.O. Customers Suspect a 23% Profit

docs.abstract: Poll shows that many customers of HMO's believe that half their premiums go toward HMO expenses and profit rather than medical care; Excellus Inc, which runs Blue Cross in upstate New York and sponsored poll, says it spends 90 percent of premiums on medical care (S)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

byline.original: By Hope Reeves (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

docs.lead_paragraph: MariBel Garcia lives near several good doctor's offices and hospitals, but as far as she is concerned they might as well not be there at all. Her housecleaning and restaurant jobs have never provided health insurance. Few local facilities have Spanish-speaking staff members. Even making an appointment, given her limited English skills, is a daunting, often humiliating, experience. ''They don't understand my language, my culture, my issues,'' said Ms. Garcia, 40, who came to the United States from El Salvador 15 years ago and is now a legal resident. ''I would rather wait and see a doctor on a visit to El Salvador than go through that difficulty.''

headline.main: A Neighborhood Clinic Helps Fill the Gap for Latinos Without Health Care

docs.abstract: La Clinica del Pueblo is filling health care gap in Latino community of Washington, DC; clinic operates primarily in Spanish, runs outreach programs and treats patients regardless of legal status, health insurance coverage or ability to pay; similar facilities are springing up across nation; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hugh D. Brauer, 73, has a one-man legal practice in Highland, Ind. He does a little debt collection for a nearby furniture store, and he says he tries to treat people fairly. ''I conduct myself in a moral, appropriate way,'' Mr. Brauer said. Indeed, he said, many of those he has collected from have tried to hire him as a lawyer.

headline.main: Law to Protect Debtors Can Be a Windfall for Lawyers

docs.lead_paragraph: JEANNE RICHARDS is an ardent believer in mammography. During a routine mammogram in 1995, doctors discovered a lump deep in her left breast. It turned out to be a benign cyst. But since then Mrs. Richards, 57, has received a mammogram twice a year though the American Cancer Society recommends only one annually. ''When I go to any doctor, I am a nervous basket case until I find out I am O.K.,'' she said.
docs.abstract: Article on decline in number of breast screening centers in New Jersey and nationwide, which is resulting in longer waiting times and declining service; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Few disappearing acts have been as astonishing as the evaporation of hundreds of thousands of people from New York City's welfare rolls. In March 1996, 1.16 million people got cash income assistance in the city -- roughly one in every seven residents or one out of 12 cases nationwide. As of August, 420,000 people were still on the rolls.

headline.main: From Welfare to Work, and Then, to What?; Women Describe Their Lives Off Public Assistance, for Better and Worse

docs.abstract: Article on present situation of several women who are among 740,000 people who have left New York City's welfare rolls since March 1996; interviews with several dozen women find their material well-being is more clouded than either side of public debate allows; most say they are better off without welfare and are pleased with decision to move toward economic independence even in troubling economic times; some have stories that read like Horatio Alger tales, but others rely on patchwork of support from relatives, lovers and government (M)

keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: ABOUT one-third of all employees never bother to shop for a health insurance plan, opting to stick with their old plans year after year, according to a recent survey of 750 employees by Cigna Healthcare. But as employers change options -- as many plan to do this month -- it's important to at least review the offerings. Following are some questions to consider: Is your doctor still in your plan? If not, there may be another plan in which he or she is participating.

headline.main: Personal Business; How to Find Insurance That Fits

docs.abstract: List of questions to consider in reviewing health insurance plans' offerings offered by employer (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: RISA LAVIZZO-MOUREY was in middle school when she had her first lesson in the economics of health care. The Boeing Company was laying off workers, leaving them without health insurance. Her parents, both doctors practicing in a fairly poor Seattle neighborhood, had to decide each month which patients to bill. ''I asked, 'What does insurance have to do with medical care?' '' Ms. Lavizzo-Mourey recalled recently.
docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Risa Lavisso-Mourey, geriatric specialist who has been named chief executive of Robert Wood Johnson Foundation; foundation is US's largest philanthropy devoted to health and health care; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SHALIA WATTS, a government employee from Sacramento, received some upsetting news in June: the health maintenance organization to which she belongs, Health Net, will no longer be available through her employer next year. At the same time, she said, she found that the monthly premium for the Blue Shield H.M.O. she chose as a replacement would be $110, almost double what she pays now. Co-payments for her prescription-drug plan already rose this year, she said, from $5 to a scale ranging from $10 to $30. ''I'm starting to feel the financial pressure; it really adds up,'' said Ms. Watts, 48, who earns about $48,000 a year as a disability insurance program representative for the California Employment Development Department.

headline.main: Personal Business; Health Plans Are Offering Fewer Choices and Higher Costs

docs.abstract: Many American workers are finding that their health insurance plans offer fewer choices and higher costs, along with new options that reflect employers' moves to reduce costs and shift more responsibility for health care to their employees; increases in premium costs are far greater than gains in salaries or overall inflation; photo; graph (M)
